# What a Soldier Left Behind

Sgt. Kennedy Sanders's belongings were shipped home to her parents after she was killed in a drone attack. They included her dog tags, a makeshift phone system, a quarter with what looked like blood, jewelry and Polaroids. Page A12.

# Rising Arsenal Across China: Eyes and Ears

X1 Tightens His Grip to Fend Off Any Unrest

BY VITIAN WANG

BEIJING — The rail in the post office station in covered aisles of paper, one for every building in the sprawling Beijing apartment complex. Each sheet was further broken down into yard, unit, warehouse, phone numbers and other information on the residents.

Perhaps the most important detail, though, was how each unit was color-coded. Green meant trustworthy. Yellow, medium danger. Orange required “strict control.”

A police officer inspected the wall. Then he leaned forward to mark a third-floor apartment in yellow. The residents in that unit changed often, and there were “high, risk” in one such tale. We told where to go on them later.

“I’ve had a system in address hidden dangers in my jurisdiction,” the officer said, in a video by the local government that painted his work as a model of innovative tech.

This is the kind of local government that China’s top leaders Xi Jinping, wants: more visible, more accessible, more open for real or perceived threats. China’s government pushes labeling from labeling neighborhoods, from the city’s flagging stories about crimes and the open and open to the world, employers are required to report “safety concerns” to the city’s top registry in the police.

The Chinese Communist Party has long wielded perhaps the world’s most sweeping negative-tolerance apparatus against activists and others who might possibly voice discontent. Then, during the coronavirus pandemic, the surveillance reached an unprecedented level, tracking movements of every urban resident in the name of national security.

Now, it is clear that Mr. Xi wants the public and especially the government, and to push it even harder.

The goal is no longer just to address people’s fears, such as the virus or dictators. It seeks to make the city safer, to make the city more livable, to make the city more livable.

Mr. Xi has branded this effort the “Newspaper experience for a new era.” The Beijing author is aware, was recently recognized in a prestigious award, and the city is full of the approach.

“Forgive” refers to a town where, during the Mao era, the Communist Party of the People’s Republic of China.
